body.p: The objectives of this lab are to:

ul.li: Be sure that you can log on the computer system
Have a hands-on introduction to Python
Know of a few Unix tools to derive word statistics
Know of the main functions of scikit-learn

body.p: Each student will have to run a short program at home on spelling correction and comment it. This part is compulsory as well as handing in the report. This is to be sure that you have the elementary Python programming skills we need for the course. See the last section of the page.
The first lab session will take place on

ul.li: Group 1: Tuesday, September 4 from 8:15 to 10:00 in the Beta room
Group 2: Tuesday, September 4 from 13:15 to 15:00 in the Beta room
Group 3: Tuesday, September 4 from 15:15 to 16:00 in the Beta room

body.p:
There can be last minute changes. Please always check the official times here:
https://se.timeedit.net/web/lu/db1/lth1/
In this lab, we will review the Python syntax and some tools. Attendance is not compulsory, but you have to run the spell checker by Peter Norvig at home to make sure you understand Python.

ol.li: We will use Python 3 and the Anaconda distribution in the labs: https://www.continuum.io/downloads. Anaconda has most packages we need for the course.

Anaconda is available on the lab machines. You add it to your path by running:
$ initcs
If you use a personal machine, you will have to download and install it.

regex is one of the few modules that is not in Anaconda: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/regex/.
regex can handle regular expressions and Unicode. It should already be installed on the computer network. On your personal machine, install it with pip:
python -m pip install --upgrade regex

As programming environment (IDE), we recommend PyCharm: https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/. The community edition is free.
PyCharm is not available on the lab computers. You will add the Python plugin to IntelliJ instead. Run:
$ intellij-idea-community
then Configure and add Python

Instead of an IDE, you may prefer Jupyter notebooks to create cells that you can run interactively. You start jupyter with:
$ jupyter notebook

On LTH machines, the regex module is not available from PyCharm by default. You need first to configure your environment. To do so, in the File menu, select Settings..., then Project and Project Interpreter. In the Project Interpreter box, on the top of the right pane, add the new interpreter by pressing the cog icon, and Add... Then select Anaconda Python: /usr/local/anaconda/bin/python

body.p: In the lab session, your instructors will walk you through Python, Unix, and scikit-learn. You will:

ol.li: run all the code in the chapter: A Tour of Python
count the words of a text with Unix tools

run the quick introduction to scikit-learn:
http://scikit-learn.org/stable/tutorial/basic/tutorial.html
and understand fit() and predict():
Run the spell checker here: http://norvig.com/spell-correct.html. Use Python 3 and make sure you understand all the syntax;
Hand in an individual comment of this program on one to two pages.
